Welcome to Emotion-Recognition’s documentation!¶

lib.preprocess.detectObject(object_cascade, img)[source]¶

Finds the bounding boxes around objects within an image.

Parameters

  • object_cascade (cv2.CascadeClassifier) – Cascade classifier to detect object.

  • img (numpy.ndarray) – 3 dimensional array representing a BGR image.

Returns

Two dimensional array of shape (n,4). Here, n represents the number of detected objects. Each object has 4 coordinates representing its bounding box.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

lib.preprocess.normFaces(img, faces)[source]¶

Crop, convert to grayscale, resize, and normalize, faces identified by the bounding boxes in input img.

Parameters

  • img (numpy.ndarray) – 3 dimensional array representing a BGR image.

  • faces (numpy.ndarray) – Two dimensional array of shape (n,4). Here, n represents the number of detected faces. Each face has 4 coordinates representing its bounding box.

Returns

3 dimensional array of shape (n,48,48). Here, n represents the number of detected faces. Each face is cropped, converted to grayscale, and normalized to 48pixel-by-48pixel.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

class lib.util.plotter(name, scale, maxRange=[1, 1])[source]¶

Graph plot generator

Parameters

  • name (str) – Name of graph to plot.

  • scale (str) – Scale of the y axis. Options supported are ‘linear’ and ‘log’.

  • maxRange (list, optional) – Maximum range of x and y axis represented by a list [max_x, max_y]. By default [1,1].

draw(scale=None)[source]¶

Draws and displays the graph to screen. Additionally, it adds the graph handle to a global Handle resource list.

Parameters

scale (str, optional) – scale of the y axis, by default None

Returns

Returns int 0 to indicate graph was succesfully plotted.

Return type

int

Raises

NotImplementedError – If no appropriate scale type is set for graph axes.

Todo

Implement true graph plotting function.

Example¶

Script: /example/emoRecStream.py

This script captures video from an attached webcam at video device port 0. A machine learning algorithm classifies the facial expression for each detected face into one of 7 categories, namely,

  • “0”: “angry”,

  • “1”: “disgust”,

  • “2”: “fear”,

  • “3”: “happy”,

  • “4”: “sad”,

  • “5”: “surprise”,

  • “6”: “neutral”.

The captured frames are displayed in a window with bounding boxes and predicted emotion labels around any deteced faces.

This file can also be imported as a module and contains the following functions:

  • main - the main function of the script
